title: Tracee Ellis Ross Reveals TSA Pulled a 'Private' Rechargeable Item Out of Her Bag at Security
description: The 'Solo Traveling' star recounted the awkward airport run-in during the Aug. 15 episode of 'Jimmy Kimmel Live'
content:
NEED TO KNOW
• None Tracee Ellis Ross had an awkward experience during a recent TSA screening
• None The Solo Traveling star joined guest host Nicole Byer on Jimmy Kimmel Live and revealed agents found her "private bedside table things"
• None The self-described "rule follower" said she put the items in her carry-on because they contain a rechargeable battery

Tracee Ellis Ross had an uncomfortable moment during a recent TSA screening.

On the Aug. 15 episode of Jimmy Kimmel Live, Ross joined guest host Nicole Byer to promote her new show Solo Traveling with Tracee Ellis Ross. During the interview, Byer asked the star about the weirdest thing she has ever packed.

“Oh, goodness me,” the actress, 52, said as she readjusted in her chair.

The black-ish star explained that while on a trip for her new show, her bag was pulled aside by the TSA for extra screening. The agents then opened her carry-on and “went through every single little bag” inside.

“One of my bags has bedside table things in it,” she said. “Private bedside table things.”

Then, Ross recreated the face the agent who found it gave her: a knowing half-grin with a finger point.

“I was so embarrassed, I was so embarrassed,” she repeated. “And now I have shared it with all of you.”

In her defense, Ross cited a well-known air travel rule as the reason why the items were placed in her carry-on specifically

“Because I’m such a rule follower, anything [with] a rechargeable battery goes in your carry-on,” she explained behind a laugh.



“That goes in your carry-on,” she added with a hair flip.

Byer added her own embarrassing airport security experience too.

“I went to Amsterdam and I bought a bunch of rubber duckies and I had them in my carry-on, but nobody was like ‘You go girl,’” she said. “They openly laughed at me. It was so mean.”

Elsewhere in the interview, Ross spoke about the inspiration behind her Roku Channel show.

“I have been solo traveling since I was like 24, 25, I take at least one maybe two solo travel trips a year, and I’m 52, it’s been a long run,” she explained.



She added: “I went on a trip, my regular summer trip, and a guy that was helping me at the airport was like ‘Oh my god, we wait every year for your first dips, we wait for your outfits in Paris, it’s like an event on Instagram.’”



Ross, who was shocked to learn there was a big following behind her solo travels, contacted her manager to see if they could “turn up the volume” on it. From there, the show was born.

Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer​​, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.

In the series, which premiered on July 25, Ross traveled to Morocco, Spain and Mexico.

The self-described “over packer” told Byer she typically checks anywhere from three to eight bags in addition to her carry-on. She lives on a strict “BIA” policy — “Bring it all.”

“When I go on vacation, it’s my opportunity to like wear all my beautiful things and then I also, of course, might have to plan for disaster, which happened in Spain,” she teased.

keywords.name: Solo Traveling with Tracee Ellis Ross

summary: Tracee Ellis Ross, a self-proclaimed "rule follower" who travels solo, had an uncomfortable moment during a recent TSA screening when agents found her "private bedside table things" in her carry-on. The items were found because they contain a rechargeable battery. Ross joined guest host Nicole Byer on Jimmy Kimmel Live to promote her new show, Solo Traveling with Tracee. She explained that while on a trip for her show, her bag was pulled aside for extra screening and agents opened her carry on to inspect all her bags. In her defense, she cited a well-known air travel rule as the reason for the items being placed in her luggage.
shortSummary: Tracee Ellis Ross experienced an awkward TSA screening involving "private bedside table things” in her carry-on, highlighting her strict travel rules.

scraped_sources.text: Southwest Airlines Is Placing New Restrictions on Portable Batteries The airline is the first of the major companies to place this restriction on lithium batteries By Rachel McRady Rachel McRady Rachel McRady is a Digital News Editor at PEOPLE. She has been an entertainment journalist for more than a decade, previously working for E! News, Entertainment Tonight, and Us Weekly. People Editorial Guidelines Published on May 22, 2025 01:37PM EDT 2 Comments Southwest Airlines plane. Credit : Kevin Carter/Getty NEED TO KNOW Southwest Airlines is implementing new restrictions surrounding lithium batteries Portable batteries to charge devices cannot be used while inside bagsIn 2025, there have been 22 confirmed incidents involving lithium batteries on planes Southwest Airlines is implementing new restrictions surrounding portable batteries in the interest of passenger safety. The airliner is now prohibiting the use of portable batteries to charge devices while inside bags because they can pose a fire risk, Southwest Airlines tells PEOPLE. The decision makes Southwest the first of the major airlines to implement the safety measure. The restriction will take effect on May 28 and will require passengers “keep portable charging devices visible while in use during flight,” the company shared with PEOPLE in a statement. Batteries. Getty “Using portable charging devices while stored in a bag or overhead bin will no longer be permitted,” Southwest shared. As for the reason behind the decision, the airlines noted, “Nothing is more important to Southwest than the safety of its customers and employees.” Highlighting multiple incidents of overheated batteries on airplanes this year alone, Southwest concluded, “In the rare event a lithium battery overheats or catches fire, quick access is critical. Keeping power banks in plain sight allows for faster intervention and helps protect everyone onboard.” Passengers waiting to board a flight. Getty The PEOPLE App is now available in the Apple App Store! Download it now for the most binge-worthy celeb content, exclusive video clips, astrology updates and more! Related Stories Southwest Airlines Joins List of Airlines Banning Emotional Support Animals from Their Flights Southwest Airlines Is Ending Open Seating Policy and Will Assign Seats Starting in 2025 The Federal Aviation Administration currently has a limit of two portable batteries per passenger and notes that they are not allowed in checked luggage. According to the F.A.A., there have been 22 incidents involving lithium batteries on planes in 2025 and 11 others still pending verification. Incidents reached a new high in 2024 with 89 total. Close Leave a Comment Read more: Lifestyle Travel Airline Travel

Nicole Byer Reveals Her Hilarious Ultimate Travel Hack: ‘Be Weird on Planes’ (Exclusive) The ‘Nailed It!’ host spilled her winter travel knowledge while chatting with PEOPLE about her new partnership with Destination Canada By Natalia Senanayake Natalia Senanayake Natalia Senanayake is an Editorial Assistant, Lifestyle at PEOPLE. She covers all things travel and home, from celebrities' luxury mansions to breaking travel news. People Editorial Guidelines Published on December 5, 2023 01:25PM EST Nicole Byer teamed up with Destination Canada to launch the four-part travel series, Canadian Crash Course. Credit : Destination Canada/Markian Lozowchuk Nicole Byer has no shortage of travel tips — including a few you might need to be as bold as the Nailed It! host to try for yourself. "Be weird on planes,” she tells PEOPLE during an exclusive interview for her partnership with Destination Canada, Essentially, do what you need to in order to feel comfortable, no shame. “Sometimes I'll bring under eye masks, like a weirdo, and put those on, on the plane,” explains the host, who's known for her boisterous attitude and hot takes on the Netflix baking competition series. “Just be weird on planes. Bring [sheet] masks, do you.” 'Masked Singer' Guest Judge Nicole Byer Shocks All by Correctly Guessing Eliminated Contestant The Good Burger 2 actress also revealed her hack for never checking a bag at the airport and shared her honest opinion about the season that gets the worst rap: winter. For starters, the host says the key to traveling light is to make full use of every nook and cranny in your luggage. “I never check a bag and I always have a carry on,” she says. “I tetris things together and there's no part of my suitcase that isn't utilized. I just fit everything really beautifully.” Nicole Byer tried her hand at Canadian winter sports in the four-part video series. Destination Canada/Markian Lozowchuk Another piece of space-saving advice she gives is to always bring a scarf on a plane because it can “double as a blanket on the plane, especially if you have a long one." A bathing suit is also a packing must whether you’re traveling somewhere cold or hot, “because sometimes hotels will have indoor pools,” and you never know when you might need it, she says. Plus, it doesn’t take up too much space. Nicole Byer Twerks and John Cena Is Seriously Funny in the '80s-tastic Wipeout Teaser (Exclusive) A still from the cold plunge segment of Canadian Crash Course featuring Nicole Byer. Destination Canada/Markian Lozowchuk While Byer has a number of destinations on her travel bucket list — from the South of France to India — she also stands by her opinion that cold destinations like Canada are worth visiting in the winter. The star says that she likes winter for several reasons. “You can be outside in the cold and you get to bundle up. I do like sweaters. You also don't have to go outside. You can stay inside and put a fire on. So, winter is a delightful time of the year.” Nicole Byer Shares Script on How to Talk About Racism to White Kids: 'Read It Verbatim' In November, Byer partnered with Destination Canada — the country’s official tourism site owned by the Canadian government — to launch a four-part video series called Canadian Crash Course. Throughout the comedy series, Byer takes on a few winter activities that are outside of her comfort zone and shares her tips for navigating the icy season along the way. Never miss a story — sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from juicy celebrity news to compelling human-interest stories. Nicole Byer gracefully falls while skiing in the hilarious Canadian Crash Course skit. Destination Canada/Markian Lozowchuk Of the partnership, the Why Won’t You Date Me? podcast host explains, “The fun message it sends to travelers is, ‘Come to Canada during the winter. There's fun stuff to do. The cold isn't so bad. Canada has lots of beautiful places, and everyone's nice!" Close Read more: Lifestyle Travel

Look Back at the 'Black-ish' Cast's Cutest Moments Ahead of the Final Season ABC's Black-ish starring Tracee Ellis Ross, Anthony Anderson, Marsai Martin, Yara Shahidi, Marcus Scribner, and Miles Brown is coming to an end after eight seasons. See the cast's cutest moments together as the final season premieres on Jan. 4 By Kelsie Gibson Kelsie Gibson Kelsie Gibson is the SEO Editor of PEOPLE. She has been working at PEOPLE since 2021. She was formerly at POPSUGAR, Bustle, Tiger Beat and Her Campus. People Editorial Guidelines Published on January 4, 2022 02:12PM EST 01 of 14 Meet the Johnson Family Craig Sjodin/Disney General Entertainment Content via Getty Images Black-ish, which is created by Kenya Barris, debuted its first season in September 2014. The series starred, clockwise from left, Marcus Scribner, Tracee Ellis Ross, Anthony Anderson, Laurence Fishburne, Marsai Martin, Miles Brown, and Yara Shahidi. It marked many of the young cast's breakthrough roles, including a then-10-year-old Martin and Brown, then 9. 02 of 14 Award-Winning Series ROBYN BECK/AFP via Getty Images Black-ish has received numerous accolades over the years including several NAACP Image Awards. In February 2015, the cast took home outstanding comedy series at the award show. 03 of 14 Hitting the Red Carpet Amanda Edwards/WireImage In April 2015, the cast walked one of their first red carpets together as they attended the Black-ish ATAS Event in LA together. 04 of 14 Another Big Win Tommaso Boddi/WireImage At the NAACP Image Awards in February 2016, the cast raked in even more awards, including outstanding comedy series and big wins for Anthony Anderson, Tracee Ellis Ross, Marsai Martin, and Marcus Scribner. 05 of 14 Big Happy Family Matt Winkelmeyer/Getty Images The stars were all smiles as they attended PaleyFest LA in March 2016. 06 of 14 Third Time's a Charm Gregg DeGuire/WireImage For the third year in a row, Black-ish took home outstanding comedy series at the NAACP Image Awards in 2017. 07 of 14 Celebrate Good Times Richard Harbaugh / Disney General Entertainment Content via Getty Images The cast joined together to celebrate season 3 at a For Your Consideration event in LA in April 2017. 08 of 14 Another Season in the Books Aaron Poole/Disney General Entertainment Content via Getty Images The stars posed for a group photo at the season 4 wrap party in March 2018. Around the same time, the Yara Shahidi-led spinoff series titled Grown-ish debuted on Freeform. 09 of 14 A Winning Streak Maury Phillips/Getty Images In 2018, Black-ish took home outstanding comedy series at the NAACP Image Awards for the fourth time. 10 of 14 Family Game Night Byron Cohen via Getty Images In February 2019, the Black-ish cast competed against the cast of The Goldbergs on Celebrity Family Feud. 11 of 14 A New Chapter Heidi Gutman via Getty Images In October 2019, the cast celebrated season 6 with a panel at PaleyFest NY. 12 of 14 Family Time Richard Cartwright via Getty Images Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, the cast didn't appear on the red carpet together very much, but they did join together for a special episode in season 7 as Earl "Pops" Johnson (Laurence Fishburne) and Ruby Johnson (Jenifer Lewis) got remarried. 13 of 14 All Grown Up Richard Cartwright via Getty Images The cast looked so grown-up in this promotional image for season 7 in 2021. 14 of 14 End of an Era ABC In celebration of the final season, the Black-ish cast recreated their season 1 poster, right down to the bright outfits. Read more: Entertainment TV Scripted TV Shows Close

argos_summary: Tracee Ellis Ross recounted an awkward TSA screening on the August 15 episode of Jimmy Kimmel Live, when agents opened her carry‑on and found a rechargeable bedside item she had kept in line with airline rules. She used the moment to promote her new Roku Channel series, Solo Traveling, and shared how her solo‑traveling reputation has grown into a dedicated following. The article also highlights Southwest Airlines’ May 28 restriction on portable batteries in bags and includes guest host Nicole Byer’s own airport mishaps and travel‑packing tips.
